content.title: Nutrition Support in the ICU
content.summary: Adequate nutrition support is essential for critically ill patients to prevent muscle wasting, immune dysfunction, and impaired wound healing. Early enteral nutrition (within 24-48 hours) is preferred over parenteral nutrition when the gut is functional. Protein requirements are increased (1.2-2.0 g/kg/day). Permissive underfeeding may be beneficial initially. Refeeding syndrome is a dangerous complication when feeding malnourished patients. Guidelines recommend against routine GRV monitoring and support trophic or full feeding based on clinical context.
key_points: Early enteral nutrition (24-48 hours) preferred if gut functional
Protein: 1.2-2.0 g/kg/day; often higher in critical illness
Calories: 25-30 kcal/kg/day; permissive underfeeding may be acceptable initially
Trophic feeds (10-20 mL/hr) maintain gut integrity even if full feeding not possible
Refeeding syndrome: Phosphate, K, Mg drop when feeding malnourished; start low, go slow
Parenteral nutrition: Reserve for gut failure; start day 7 if EN not possible
content.statement: ICU nutrition prioritizes early enteral feeding within 24-48 hours with adequate protein (1.2-2.0 g/kg/day), monitoring for refeeding syndrome in malnourished patients, and reserving parenteral nutrition for gastrointestinal failure.

explanation.intuition: The gut is not just for digestion - it's an immune organ. Starving the gut leads to bacterial translocation and immune suppression. Even trickle feeds keep the gut alive and functioning. Think of nutrition as another medication that needs to be dosed carefully.
explanation.key_insight: Protein is more important than total calories in critical illness. Muscle wasting is rapid (up to 1 kg/day) and contributes to prolonged weakness and ventilator dependence. Adequate protein (1.5-2 g/kg/day) may help preserve muscle, while overfeeding calories causes harm.
explanation.technical_details: Calculate IBW for dosing: Males: 50 + 2.3(height in inches - 60); Females: 45.5 + 2.3(height in inches - 60). Energy targets: 25-30 kcal/kg/day (may use indirect calorimetry). Monitor prealbumin (half-life ~2 days) for acute changes. Refeeding syndrome: phosphate drops as cells take up glucose; can cause respiratory failure, arrhythmias.

definitions_glossary.enteral_nutrition: EN; feeding via the GI tract (oral, NG, NJ, PEG)
definitions_glossary.parenteral_nutrition: PN/TPN; IV nutrition bypassing GI tract
definitions_glossary.trophic_feeds: Low-rate enteral feeding (10-20 mL/hr) to maintain gut integrity
definitions_glossary.refeeding_syndrome: Electrolyte shifts when feeding malnourished; phosphate, K, Mg drop
definitions_glossary.GRV: Gastric residual volume; previously used to assess tolerance
definitions_glossary.aspiration: Inhalation of gastric contents into airway
definitions_glossary.protein_catabolism: Breakdown of muscle protein during critical illness
definitions_glossary.indirect_calorimetry: Measurement of metabolic rate via oxygen consumption
definitions_glossary.PEG: Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy; surgical feeding tube
definitions_glossary.prealbumin: Short half-life protein marker for nutritional status
definitions_glossary.IBW: Ideal body weight; used for nutrition calculations

laboratory.note: Both affected by inflammation; not reliable in acute illness

enteral_nutrition.timing: Start within 24-48 hours of ICU admission if GI tract functional

access.NJ_tube: Post-pyloric; for high aspiration risk, gastroparesis

initiation.starting_rate: 20-30 mL/hr; advance every 4-8 hours as tolerated
initiation.trophic_feeding: 10-20 mL/hr if full feeding not tolerated

parenteral_nutrition.timing: Consider if EN not possible by day 7 (EPaNIC trial suggests no early PN)

components.lipid_emulsion: Fat source; 10 kcal/g; limit to prevent hypertriglyceridemia

calories.permissive_underfeeding: 15-20 kcal/kg/day in first week may be acceptable

protein.renal_failure: May need adjustment; dialysis patients need higher

tolerance_monitoring.GRV: No longer routinely recommended; does not predict aspiration

refeeding_syndrome.mechanism: Glucose shifts metabolism from fat; cells uptake electrolytes

special_situations.liver_failure: Avoid excessive protein if encephalopathy; branched-chain amino acids
special_situations.renal_failure: Moderate protein restriction if not on dialysis
special_situations.pancreatitis: Early EN preferred; nasojejunal if severe

definition.@value: Provision of adequate nutrition to critically ill patients via enteral or parenteral routes

scopeNote.@value: Early enteral nutrition preferred; adequate protein critical

medicalCode.description: Nutritional substance into upper GI via tube

learning_objectives: Calculate protein and calorie requirements in critical illness
Compare enteral vs parenteral nutrition indications
Initiate and advance enteral nutrition appropriately
clinical_pearls: Start EN within 24-48 hours if gut works - don't wait for bowel sounds
Protein (1.5-2 g/kg/day) is more important than total calories
GRV monitoring is NOT recommended - it doesn't predict aspiration
Refeeding syndrome: give thiamine, replace phosphate BEFORE starting feeds in high-risk
Trophic feeds (10-20 mL/hr) maintain gut integrity even if full feeding impossible
common_misconceptions: Wait for bowel sounds to start EN - not necessary
High GRV means stop feeds - no longer recommended
Albumin reflects nutritional status - it's an acute phase reactant
All patients need 100% of calorie goal immediately - permissive underfeeding may be ok
